Answers.human: EDIT , Nov 21 : By popular demand , now includes Midrange decks and Limited formats . Also , a new section on where players get their cards . Magic : The Gathering is a collectable card game . It can be played in several different formats , but in the most common , two players create decks out of the cards they own and play against each other . Generally , the cards in a deck are either lands or spells . Lands provide the energy needed to cast spells , and spells usually do one of the following : - Summon a creature that can fight for you or an artifact that you can use . ( * * Creatures * * and * * Artifacts * * ) - Create a lasting effect that affects the game as a whole or one or more cards in play . ( * * Enchantments * * ) - Create an instantaneous effect that affects one or more cards in play or an effect that lasts a single turn . ( * * Sorceries * * and * * Instants * * ) - Summon a sort of  teammate  that has its own abilities . ( * * Planeswalkers * * ) The primary goal is to run your opponent out of life points by attacking him with creatures or damaging him directly with spells . There are other ways to win , such as running your opponent out of cards in his deck . The gameplay is complex . The players take turns , but many types of spells can be cast on an opponent 's turn , or in response to a spell that they are trying to cast . A critical play by one player may be countered by the other , and that counter itself countered by the first . There are many thousands of cards out there , and you are not expected to know about them all . The Comprehensive Rules ( * not * including the text of cards ) are nearly two hundred pages , although a lot of that consists of old mechanics that are rarely used or highly - specified details that are rarely relevant . The learning curve is pretty steep , but a few games suffice to learn the basic rules . The complexity is more similar to Dungeons and Dragons than to most card games . A key feature of M : tG is the concept of * * color * * . There are five colors : Red , Green , White , Blue , Black . Each is  allied  to two others and  opposed  to the two others . Most spells require mana of a certain color to cast , which is produced by different types of land cards . Each color has distinct strengths and weaknesses – for example , blue has the best counterspells , but it 's not very good at simply hitting things . A given deck will usually use from one to three colors of card , although in some situations decks with four or five colors can work . In addition , it is often considered that there are three general archetypes of deck ( with a * lot * of variation within each category ) : - * * Aggro * * decks focus on dealing damage ASAP to win ASAP . They usually have cheap creatures (  weenies  ) that can be used right away and  buff-type spells to eke out a few more points of damage . They usually win fast or not at all , because they often ca n't stand up to the more powerful creatures and spells that are played later in the game . - * * Control * * decks focus on preventing the opponent from acting until the player is ready to win with powerful spells or abilities . They run a lot of counterspells , destruction spells , and things that make action more expensive for the opponent , along with a few creatures strong on defense and disruption . They usually win by using cheap defenses against expensive attacks until they are ready to overwhelm the opponent with their accumulated strength , and lose if they just ca n't stay ahead of the enemy 's attacks . - * * Combo * * decks rely on a few combinations of cards that can lead to a near - instant victory . There * are * infinite combos in M : tG , but they 're designed to be difficult or resource - intensive to pull off . A combo deck will usually run ( in addition to the all - important combo pieces )  tutor  cards that let them search their deck , protection cards to guard the combo pieces , and just enough stall cards to prevent a quick defeat . A combo deck wins when it gets its combo in place before losing , and loses if it ca n't get the combo out in time or ca n't protect it long enough to use it . - * * Midrange * * decks are a common intermediate archetype between Aggro and Control . Midrange tries to beat down the opponent with damage from powerful creatures ( colloquially ,  fatties  ) rather than with cheap ones (  weenies  ) . These decks have to run enough control to stay alive until the big hitters come out . They win when they get the hitters out early enough to do lethal damage , and lose when they ca n't get the big guys out at all ( being out - controlled ) or when they just take too much of a beating too early ( being out - aggro'd ) . --- Many different kinds of people play M : tG. There are professional players who win large sums at tournaments , groups of friends who play casually on the weekends , and everything in between . If you 're playing competitively , it can be absurdly expensive , as you can not compromise on getting the perfect cards for your deck , but if you and your opponents are playing casually , it 's a lot cheaper . The most common formats are as follows . Two - player games are the norm for tournaments , but casual matches are often multiplayer . * * Constructed * * formats call for pre - constructed decks built from each player 's personal collection : - * * Standard * * : Decks are made of cards printed in about the last 18 months . - * * Modern * * : Decks are made of cards printed since about 2003 ( minus a ban list ) . - * * Legacy * * : Decks are made of * any * cards ( minus a ban list ) . - * * Vintage * * : Decks are made of * any * cards ( minus a * very small * ban list ) . - * * Commander * * ( or  EDH  ): Decks are made of * any * cards ( minus a ban list ) , but limited to one of each card . One creature card is designated as your  commander  and is nearly always available for summoning . A popular multiplayer format . * * Limited * * formats feature decks made on the spot from a limited pool of cards : - * * Sealed * * : Each player opens several randomized booster packs and makes a deck from the contents . - * * Draft * * : A group of players open many packs and use a system to pick their cards from the contents , then build a deck from what they have . These formats cost money each time to play , because you need to buy booster packs . However , you can play them without having any of your own cards beforehand . Limited play can be a good way to pick up more cards . A relatively new casual format is * * Cube * * , in which you and your group put together a large pile of cards beforehand and use them in place of booster packs . This eliminates the recurring expense , although you need to have enough cards beforehand . There are others formats , including Conspiracy , Planechase , Pauper ( use no rare cards ) . Two - Headed Giant ( play with a partner ) , and many more . Formats that allow older cards tend to be more expensive , because the cards have been out of print for a long time . Commander is a bit cheaper than other formats that allow old cards , because you only can have one of each card ( other formats usually allow up to four of each card ) . I play Commander with my D & D group . None of us puts that much money into it , and we try to keep it more fun than competitive . Some of the players also play in local mini - tournaments on Friday nights (  Friday Night Magic  ) , usually breaking about even . --- So , where does one get cards ? Most cards come from randomized booster packs with 15 cards each . Cards from a given set are designated either common , uncommon , rare , or  mythic rare  . You can buy booster packs for around $ 3.50 USD from retailers , or you can buy them as part of a limited tournament . There are also pre - made decks that you can buy directly from Wizards of the Coast . Each one has a theme and cards intended to work together . You wo n't win any tournaments with a pre - made deck , but it can be a good starting point . In addition , there are a couple of products intended for beginners , such as the  Deck - builder 's toolkit  with a semi - randomized selection of cards and a big stack of common lands . ( Common lands are dirt cheap , but it would take quite a few booster packs to get enough to build a deck . ) Most M : tG players trade cards with their friends or at events to get the specific cards they need . In addition , there is a thriving market of single cards at game stores and online . Some very , very old cards are very , very rare and expensive . A single [ Black Lotus ]  can cost many thousands of dollars . But these cards are not legal in most formats , and most players will never have seen one in person . When playing casually , your group may allow the use of  proxy  cards to substitute for the pricey ones . Myself , I 've only been playing for a year or so , and I do n't actually own my own cards ! ( My friends have a ton of extra decks to lend out . ) I 'm planning to build my own Commander deck soon , and I 'll be starting from a pre - made deck from Wizards and supplementing it primarily with trades with friends and singles from the internet .

Answers.prompt: How does depression work in the brain ? And is it more physical of psychological ? ( Both cause and symptoms ) Please explain like I'm five.
Answers.llama2: Depression is a complex condition that involves both physical and psychological factors.On the physical side, depression can affect the functioning of certain brain regions and neurotransmitters (chemicals that help communicate between brain cells). For example, the hippocampus, a part of the brain that helps regulate emotions and memory, can shrink in people with depression. This can make it harder to remember positive experiences and can lead to feelings of hopelessness.Another physical factor that can contribute to depression is inflammation. When our body experiences stress or trauma, it can release chemicals that cause inflammation in the body. This can affect the brain and make it harder to regulate emotions.Now, let's talk about the psychological side of depression. Depression can also be caused by negative thoughts and beliefs that we may have learned from our experiences or from others. For example, if we have had negative experiences in the past, we may start to believe that we are not good enough or that we will never be happy. These negative beliefs can make it harder to enjoy life and can lead to feelings of sadness and hopelessness.Additionally, depression can also be caused by a lack of social support or a lack of meaningful activities in our lives. When we feel isolated or disconnected from others, it can be harder to cope with stress and difficult emotions.So, to answer your question, depression is both physical and psychological. The physical changes in the brain can contribute to the development of depression, but the psychological factors can also play a role.To explain it like you're five, imagine that your brain is like a toy box. When you're happy and feeling good, all the toys in the box are playing nicely together. But when you're sad or feeling bad, some of the toys might start to fight with each other, and it can be harder to play with them. This is kind of like what happens in the brain when we're depressed - some of the brain regions and chemicals that help us feel happy and okay might not be working as well as they should be. And sometimes, this can be caused by things that happen to us, like not having enough friends or feeling alone.

Control: When a movie company builds its own set, they have complete control over the design and layout of the space. For example, the set can be designed with safety features such as fire-resistant materials and emergency exits, which may not be available on location.4. Privacy: Building a set can provide more privacy for the actors and crew. When filming on location, there may be people nearby who can see the actors and crew, which can be distracting and may disrupt the filming process.5. Flexibility: Building a set can be more flexible than filming on location. For example, the set can be designed to be rearranged or modified as needed, which may not be possible on location.6. Cost: While it may seem like it would be cheaper to film on location, building a set can actually be more cost-effective in the long run. For example, the movie company may be able to save money on location fees and transportation costs by building the set in a studio.7. Weather: Building a set can provide more control over the weather. For example, the set can be designed with a roof or other weather-proofing features, which may not be possible on location.8. Logistics: Building a set can be more logistically convenient than filming on location. For example, the set can be designed to be easily accessible and transportable, which may not be possible on location.In conclusion, while it may seem like it would be more cost-effective to film on location, building a set can provide more control over the filming process, safety, privacy, flexibility, cost, weather, and logistics.

Other times the name is changed because it historical / cultural meaning of the original name is lost across borders . For example , Harry Potter and the Philospher 's Stone was renamed Harry Potter and the Sorcerer 's Stone for US audiences because the mythology / story surrounding the Philospher 's Stone is not part of popular US culture / common knowledge , so the name lost it 's meaning in the US and Sorcerer 's Stone was seen to make more sense . Lastly , brand names are sometimes changed because the name may have a different meaning in another culture which ( potentially ) has a negative or inappropriate connotation . For example , the Honda Fit was originally going to be called the Honda Fitta until it was discovered that ' Fitta ' roughly translates to ' pussy ' in many Nordic languages . Another example is Church 's Chicken which has been re - branded as Texas Chicken in other parts of the world where ' Church ' is assumed to have a religious connection ( as opposed to just being a person 's name ) .

Answers.prompt: How do forensic psychologists create such specific criminal profiles ? Such as the make , model and color of the car the criminal drives , the hobbies he or she might have , etc . Please explain like I'm five.
Answers.llama2: Forensic psychology is a field of study that focuses on using psychological principles to understand and address legal issues. One important task that forensic psychologists perform is creating criminal profiles, which are detailed descriptions of the characteristics and behaviors of a suspect or perpetrator. These profiles can be used to help investigators identify and apprehend criminals, and to provide insights into the motivations and actions of the perpetrator.So, how do forensic psychologists create such specific criminal profiles? Here's a simplified explanation, as if you were five years old:1. They start by looking at the crime scene and the evidence that has been collected. This can include things like fingerprints, DNA samples, and witness statements.2. Next, they talk to the investigators and ask them about the case. They might ask questions like, What did the perpetrator look like?, What kind of car was he or she driving?, and Did the perpetrator have any distinctive features or tattoos?3. The forensic psychologist will also use their knowledge of psychology to make educated guesses about the perpetrator's personality and behavior. For example, they might assume that the perpetrator is likely to be someone who is intelligent and cunning, but also impulsive and reckless.4. They will also use their knowledge of human behavior to make predictions about the perpetrator's actions and motivations. For example, they might predict that the perpetrator will try to cover their tracks by destroying evidence or lying about their involvement in the crime.5. Finally, the forensic psychologist will use all of this information to create a detailed profile of the perpetrator. This profile will include information about the perpetrator's age, gender, physical appearance, personality traits, and behavior patterns. It may also include information about the perpetrator's hobbies, interests, and any other relevant details.So, in summary, forensic psychologists create criminal profiles by looking at the evidence, talking to investigators, using their knowledge of psychology, and making educated guesses about the perpetrator's personality and behavior. They use all of this information to create a detailed profile of the perpetrator, which can help investigators identify and catch the criminal.

Thus the client , whose traffic statistics are most correlated to the exit node traffic are chosen as the victim and verified . Basically , if the NSA controlled a service you were trying to access via Tor , they could send specially shaped packets to act as a sort of label . Even though the data is encrypted and anonymised through Tor ( between the entry and exit nodes ) , if the NSA controlled a lot of routers or major Internet exchange points , they could still track the special packets from the server to the first exit - node , through the middlemen , and finally ( and imperatively ) back through the original entry node & back to your original connection . It describes what elements are in the page and how they 're organized ( elements such as text , images , buttons and links ) . However , HTML originally did n't include the ability to show graphics , animations or videos ( other than pre - rendered images and animated gifs ) . HTML did provide the ability to include embedded objects , which would require the user to install a plugin that could display them . One such common plugin was Flash , which was basically another small program that runs inside your browser ( another such plugin is Java which can display Java Applets , but they 're hardly in use anymore ) . So developers could use Flash to create things like games ( such as the ones you 'll find in the link ) and video players ( such as YouTube ) . HTML5 introduces new features to HTML , mainly the support for the < canvas > and < video > elements . These tags could be used to display graphics and videos without the need for an external plugin , and were handled by the browser and not by the plugin . HTML5 introduces many other new features , but these are the ones that are most relevant to this discussion ( HTML5 vs Flash ) . The main advantage of HTML5 is that it 's a standard that 's supported ( or should be supported ) by every browser . On the contrary , Flash is no longer supported by Apple 's devices , and by Android 's stock browser . Another disadvantage of Flash is that it 's considered slow and inefficient .

Answers.prompt: how is filibustering even a thing ? Why is filibustering even considered a valid tactic in politics ? Why is it simply not dismissed and does it have any practical uses ? Please explain like I'm five.
Answers.llama2: In the United States Senate, a filibuster is a tactic used by a minority of senators to delay or block a vote on a piece of legislation. The senator who is filibustering will continue to speak on the floor of the Senate for as long as they can, preventing the Senate from conducting other business.The purpose of filibustering is to give the minority party a voice and to prevent the majority party from ramming through legislation without proper debate and consideration. It is intended to ensure that the rights of all senators are respected and that the will of the majority is not imposed on the minority without careful deliberation.Filibustering is a valid tactic in politics because it allows for a more deliberative and inclusive process in the legislative branch of government. It gives senators the opportunity to fully consider and debate legislation, and it ensures that the voices of all senators are heard.However, filibustering can also be used as a tool of obstructionism, and it has been criticized for slowing down the legislative process and preventing the passage of important legislation. Some have argued that the filibuster rule should be eliminated or modified to make it more difficult for senators to filibuster.Despite these criticisms, the filibuster remains an important part of the Senate's rules and traditions. It is a way for senators to exercise their constitutional power and to ensure that the voices of all citizens are represented in the legislative process.In short, filibustering is a tactic used by senators to delay or block votes on legislation, and it is intended to ensure that the rights of all senators are respected and that the legislative process is more deliberative and inclusive. While it can be criticized for slowing down the process, it remains an important part of the Senate's rules and traditions.

Answers.human: Filibustering is a tactic that evolved in the Senate . It 's often called a  parliamentary procedure ,  as it results not from constitutional law but the internal rules of the legislature . In order to allow time for a bill to be discussed and debated , a 60 vote majority is required to proceed from discussion to a vote . Senators realized they could exploit this rule to keep the majority from passing a bill , unless they had a 60 - vote majority ( a  Fillibuster - proof majority .  Filibusters used to require a significant investment of time . Senators grew weary of the pain of a filibuster , and today , the mere threat of a filibuster is enough to get a bill withdrawn due to the time involved ( [ Senators in the past were known to read recipes , Shakespeare , anything in sight ]  ) Now , to your questions : Why is it valid ? Because it works for the minority party . Why is it not simply dismissed ? No majority will eliminate it because they know it will be useful to them in the future . You 'll hear of the  Nuclear Option  from time to time , a threat to eliminate the filibuster by changing the rules ( by simple majority ) . So far , it has not happened . I would n't be surprised to see it happen in the next congress - the rise of use of filibuster is unprecedented ( the filibuster itself is less than 100 years old ) and scorched - earth politicking has become more and more common inside the beltway . Does it have any practical uses ? Yes : It 's a tool for the minority party to block particularly controversial legislation .

When soldiers can’t take back their gear because they’re injured or they sadly don’t survive, their teams try to gather it up if it's safe to do so. They do this so that people who aren't supposed to have these things can’t get their hands on them.   If it's too dangerous during the fight, they might go back later when it's safer to clean up. The military officials have special procedures to either destroy this equipment on site, or to safely transport it away to keep it from entering the wrong hands.   If some gear is left behind and people find them, it's kind of like finding something that's not yours - they might keep it, sell it, or use it. Answers.human: Hey , US Army Infantryman who is actually in Afghanistan right now here . In an Infantry platoon it is the Platoon Sergeant 's job to maintain accountability of all men , weapons , and equipment . He does this by maintaining a MAL ( master authorization list ) given to him by the Company 's Armorer when weapons are signed out from the arms room . When a Soldier is injured or killed during combat operations he / she is put onto a MEDEVAC ( medical evacuation ) vehicle , whether it be a helicopter or some form of ground transportation . Prior to the Soldier being loaded all of his equipment is stripped off of him / her and retained by the unit . If the Soldier carried a crucial casualty producing weapon , like a machine gun with a higher rate of fire than the standard M4 , it will be given to the next most qualified person along with all the ammo . This is to try and maintain the combat effectiveness , AKA how many bullets you can throw at people , despite having less people . As for the gear , after it is recovered back to a FOB ( Forward Operating Base ) all gear that was worn by a casualty is inspected by people certified to determine whether it is serviceable . If an item is not serviceable and the casualty is still alive the inspectors will make an effort to send the item to the casualty 's home . It is not uncommon for Soldiers who received gunshots to their helmets to get to keep those for life . Enemy equipment is another story . In a perfect scenario where we eliminate the threat and have time to investigate any enemy equipment is gathered by a TSE team ( Tactical Site Exploitation ) on the spot and processed similar to a crime scene . Bagged , tagged , photographed , and turned into Military Intelligence for processing so they can determine ways to fight better against the enemy 's weapons and equipment . In other situations enemy equipment is destroyed on the spot to permanently prevent the enemy from using that against us . TL;DR Platoon Sergeant is responsible for recovering friendly equipment to the best of his abilities and repaired as quickly as possible . Enemy equipment is analyzed by Military intelligence or destroyed on the spot .

Answers.prompt: Why does the Double Jeopardy Clause exist ? Why are you not allowed to prosecute someone when they been pronounced not guilty , when new evidence has been found ? Please explain like I'm five.
Answers.llama2: The Double Jeopardy Clause is a rule in the United States that says you can't be tried twice for the same crime. This means that if you've already been found not guilty of a crime, the government can't try you again for that same crime, even if they find new evidence.Imagine you're playing a game of tag with your friends. You're it, and you're running around trying to catch the other kids. But just because you tagged one of your friends, it doesn't mean they're automatically out. They might be able to run away and hide again.In the same way, if the government tries to charge you with a crime and you're found not guilty, it doesn't mean you're completely innocent. The government might still think you did something wrong, but they can't keep trying you over and over again until they get the answer they want. That would be unfair!So, the Double Jeopardy Clause is like a rule that says, Okay, you've had your turn to try to catch me. I've been found not guilty, so now it's your turn to be 'it' again. It's a way of making sure that the government can't just keep trying you over and over again for the same crime, and that you have some protection from unfair prosecution.

Answers.chatGpt3: The Double Jeopardy Clause is a part of the Fifth Amendment to the United States Constitution. It states that no person shall be subject for the same offense to be twice put in jeopardy of life or limb. This means that if someone is acquitted (found not guilty) of a crime, they cannot be tried again for the same crime. The Double Jeopardy Clause is designed to protect people from being subjected to the stress and expense of multiple trials for the same crime. It also helps to prevent the government from using its power to try to punish someone over and over again until it gets the result it wants. However, there are some exceptions to the Double Jeopardy Clause. For example, if new evidence is discovered that was not available at the time of the original trial, it may be possible to bring someone to trial again for the same crime. Additionally, the Double Jeopardy Clause does not apply in cases where the crime was committed in different states or in cases where the person was tried in both a state court and a federal court.

These ice crystals stick together and form flakes that fall to the ground as snow.One reason there is no thunder and lightning during a snowstorm is that snowstorms typically don't have the same kind of warm, moist air that is needed for thunderstorms. Thunderstorms need warm air to rise quickly and create towering cumulonimbus clouds that can produce lightning and thunder. Snowstorms, on the other hand, are usually associated with cold air and stable atmospheric conditions, which don't allow for the same kind of vertical growth of clouds.Another reason there is no thunder and lightning during a snowstorm is that the ice crystals in snow are much smaller and less electrically conductive than the water droplets in rain. This means that there is less ability for the ice crystals to generate electrical charges and create lightning.So, while snow and rain are both forms of precipitation, they are caused by different processes and have different properties that make thunder and lightning more likely to occur during rain showers than snowstorms.

This means avoiding the suspected allergen for a few weeks and then reintroducing it to see if symptoms return.6. Food challenge: In some cases, the doctor might perform a food challenge, where they give you a small amount of the suspected allergen in a controlled environment and monitor you for signs of an allergic reaction.Doctors don't shove a peanut in your face to test for allergies because that could be dangerous! Answers.prompt: Why is white rice cheaper than brown rice ? I do n't understand why white rice is cheaper than brown rice . Is n't there more work involved in making white rice ? AND more demand for it ? Please explain like I'm five.
Answers.llama2: It is true that white rice is generally cheaper than brown rice, but there are several reasons for this that have to do with the production process and the market demand. Here are some reasons why white rice is cheaper:1. Easier to produce: White rice is made by removing the bran and germ layers from the rice grain, which is a simpler and faster process than producing brown rice. Brown rice, on the other hand, retains the bran and germ layers, which makes it more time-consuming and labor-intensive to produce.2. Lower demand: Brown rice is not as popular as white rice in many parts of the world, which means that there is less demand for it. This lower demand means that the price of brown rice is higher because the producers have to charge more to make up for the lower volume of sales.3. Larger supply: White rice is grown in many more countries than brown rice, which means that there is a larger supply of white rice available. When there is a larger supply of something, the price tends to be lower because the producers have to compete with each other to sell their products.4. Government subsidies: In some countries, the government provides subsidies to farmers who grow rice, which helps to keep the price of white rice lower. These subsidies are not available for brown rice, which means that the price of brown rice is higher.5. Marketing and distribution: White rice is often marketed and distributed more widely than brown rice, which means that it is more widely available and easier to buy. This wider availability and easier accessibility make white rice cheaper than brown rice.So, to sum it up, the price difference between white rice and brown rice is mainly due to the differences in the production process, the demand for the two types of rice, and the government subsidies and marketing and distribution strategies.

Answers.prompt: What is a strawman arguement ? I searched for it but it uses some technical terms that I just do n't get , so what is a strawman arguement in a nutshell ? Edit : Thanks for the responses , it 's definitely more clear now . Please explain like I'm five.
Answers.llama2: I'd be happy to explain like you're five!So, imagine you're playing a game with your friends, and one of your friends is being really mean to you. They might say things like, You're so stupid! You'll never be good at this game! But here's the thing: just because your friend is saying mean things doesn't mean they're actually true.A strawman argument is like when your friend takes something you said or did, and they make it sound way worse than it really is. Then they attack that fake version of you, instead of talking about the real you. It's like they're setting up a pretend version of you, called a strawman, and then they try to knock that strawman down.For example, let's say you said, I think we should try this new game, and your friend responds by saying, Oh, so you think you're a genius now, huh? You think you know better than everyone else? That's a strawman argument, because your friend is taking what you said and making it sound like you think you're better than everyone else, when that's not really what you meant.So, a strawman argument is when someone takes what you said or did, and they make it sound worse than it really is, so they can attack that fake version instead of talking about the real you. It's like they're setting up a pretend version of you, and then they try to knock that down. Does that make sense?
Answers.llama3: I'm happy to help!Imagine you're playing a game with a friend, and you're trying to build a big, strong tower with blocks. But your friend is trying to knock it down. They start by picking up a small, weak block and saying, Oh, your tower is already falling apart because this little block is weak!That's not a fair attack, right? The strong tower can definitely withstand a small, weak block. Your friend is trying to make the tower look weaker than it really is, so they can easily knock it down.A strawman argument is like that. It's when someone takes a strong argument or idea, and then weakens it or changes it in a way that makes it easy to attack. They're trying to make the argument look silly or weak, so they can easily knock it down.Here's an example:Original argument: We should have more bike lanes in the city to reduce traffic congestion.Strawman argument: You want to spend all our tax money on bike lanes for a bunch of lazy people who can't even be bothered to drive a car!The original argument is about making the city better for everyone by reducing traffic. The strawman argument makes it sound like the idea is only for lazy people, and that's an easy target to attack!So, a strawman argument is when someone tries to make an idea look weak or silly by changing it or exaggerating it, just so they can easily knock it down. Make sense?
Answers.chatGpt3: A strawman argument is a type of argument where someone misrepresents or misunderstands someone else's position, and then attacks this misrepresented position instead of the real position. It's like building a straw man (a dummy made of straw) to knock down, instead of fighting the real person. Here's an example: Person A: I think we should recycle more because it helps the environment.Person B: But you just want to force everyone to do things your way and take away our freedom. Person B's argument is a strawman, because they misunderstood or misrepresented Person A's position. Person A never said anything about taking away freedom, they just said they think recycling is good for the environment. Person B's argument attacks this misrepresented position, instead of the real position. In other words, a strawman argument is when someone sets up a dummy version of someone else's argument and then attacks that, instead of the real argument. It's a way of avoiding a real discussion or debate by attacking a position that the other person doesn't actually hold.
Answers.chatGpt4: A strawman argument is when someone makes up a version of the other person's argument that's easy to argue against, then defeats that made-up version, instead of addressing the actual points made by the other person. It's like if you and your friend are deciding where to go play, and you want to go to the park, but your friend wants to stay home. For example, some people may have access to better education and job opportunities, which can lead to higher incomes. Wealth, or the total value of a person's assets (such as their savings, investments, and property), can be passed down from generation to generation, which can create a more unequal distribution of resources over time. Overall, while a progressive tax system can help to reduce inequality, it is just one factor among many that contribute to the overall level of inequality in a society.

Answers.prompt: What is a person 's net worth ? Does it have to do with how much money they have or what potential they have to earn more , or maybe a combination ? Also , who decides ? Please explain like I'm five.
Answers.llama2: Net worth is a term used to describe a person's total assets minus their total liabilities. In other words, it's a measure of how much money a person has, minus what they owe to others.To calculate net worth, you add up everything you own, like your savings, investments, and property, and then subtract everything you owe, like your debts and loans. If you have more assets than liabilities, your net worth is positive, and if you have more liabilities than assets, your net worth is negative.Now, let me explain it in a way that a five-year-old can understand. Imagine you have a piggy bank where you keep your money. If you have $100 in your piggy bank and you owe your mom $50, then your net worth is $100 - $50 = $50. That means you have $50 more than you owe, so you have a positive net worth!But if you only have $50 in your piggy bank and you owe your mom $100, then your net worth is $50 - $100 = -$50. That means you owe more than you have, so you have a negative net worth.So, net worth is like a special number that shows how much money you have compared to how much you owe. It's important because it can help you understand how well off you are financially, and it can also help you plan for the future and make smart decisions about money.And, just like how your mom or dad might keep track of how much money you have in your piggy bank, banks and other financial institutions can also keep track of your net worth. They might use this information to decide whether to lend you money or not.

Answers.prompt: Can US ever repay its national debt ? Is it possible to ever get the 17 or so trillion dollar debt back to 0 and how so ? Please explain like I'm five.
Answers.llama2: National debt refers to the amount of money that a country's government owes to its citizens, businesses, and foreign governments. The United States has a significant amount of national debt, currently sitting at around $17 trillion.It is possible for the US to repay its national debt, but it would require a combination of economic growth, spending cuts, and tax increases. Here's a simple explanation of how the US could potentially get its national debt back to zero:1. Economic growth: If the US economy grows, it means more people are working and earning money, which means more tax revenue for the government. The government can use this revenue to pay off some of its debt.2. Spending cuts: The government can reduce the amount of money it spends on things like defense, education, and healthcare. This would free up more money to pay off the debt.3. Tax increases: The government could raise taxes on wealthy individuals and corporations. This would bring in more revenue, which could be used to pay off the debt.4. Debt restructuring: The government could negotiate with its creditors (like you and me, if we own US government bonds) to restructure the debt. This could involve extending the repayment period or reducing the interest rate on the debt.It's important to note that reducing the national debt to zero is not always the best goal. Some economists argue that a moderate amount of debt can be beneficial for economic growth, as long as it is manageable.However, if the US government were to try to pay off its entire debt at once, it could be difficult and potentially harmful to the economy. For example, if the government were to suddenly stop spending money on important programs and services, it could lead to widespread unemployment and economic instability.So, while it is possible for the US to repay its national debt, it is not a simple process and would require careful planning and management. It's important for the government to find a balance between reducing the debt and maintaining economic stability.

( Basically you buy XX in IOUs from the government and they 'll pay you back XX plus interest after a given amount of time and these are generally seen as safe but low(er ) return parts of many investment portfolios for individuals and businesses . ) If the government is debt free , that means there are no bonds to invest in , which is n't very good for the economy . Economists might disagree on how much debt is good and how much is bad but most would agree that it 's best to have some . So that it . Our debt is big , but it 's not concerning because it 's about the same size as our GDP . It should probably be at least a little smaller , which is simple and hard because everyone knows what needs to be done ( higher taxes and lower spending ) but nobody is willing to do it . But much like needing to lose weight you ca n't just exercise more OR cut calories , you 've got to do both . And while we could one day , 20 , 30 years from now slowly get to zero with modest cuts and tax hikes , we do n't really need to or want to because it would mean lower , slower economic growth as a nation and fewer quality investment opportunities for individuals and businesses .

They found that a 16:9 aspect ratio (where the screen is taller than it is wide) was the best balance between detail and size.So, they started making laptops with a 1366x768 resolution, which is a 16:9 aspect ratio. Many software programs and games were designed to work well at this resolution, so it became the de facto standard for the industry.Over time, higher resolutions like 1920x1080 and 3840x2160 (4K) became popular, but 1366x768 remains a common resolution for laptops and other portable devices.

Answers.prompt: How come the Constitution of the US is relevant in modern cases even though it was created on 1787 ? How come it is used in very modern cases ( mostly technology related ) when such things did n't exist back then ? Please explain like I'm five.
Answers.llama2: The Constitution of the United States is still relevant today because it established a set of principles and rules that govern how the country is run and the rights of its citizens. These principles and rules are not limited to specific time periods or technologies, but are instead intended to be timeless and applicable to all situations.For example, the First Amendment protects freedom of speech, religion, and the press, regardless of whether the technology existed in 1787 or not. This means that the same principles that applied to printed newspapers and speeches in the 18th century also apply to social media and online communications today.Similarly, the Fourth Amendment protects citizens from unreasonable searches and seizures, regardless of whether the search is conducted by a human or a computer. This means that law enforcement agencies still need a warrant to search your digital devices or online communications, just like they would need a warrant to search your physical possessions.In addition, the Constitution established the principles of due process and equal protection under the law, which apply to all citizens, regardless of their race, gender, religion, or any other characteristic. This means that the government cannot discriminate against you or deny you your rights based on who you are or what you believe in.So, even though the technology and society have changed significantly since the Constitution was written, the principles and rules it established are still relevant and applicable today. This is why the Constitution is still used in modern cases, including technology-related cases, to ensure that the rights of all citizens are protected and respected.

Answers.prompt: What is Heisenberg 's uncertainty principle in layman 's terms ? EDIT : Past the basics i.e.  The more we know about something 's speed , the less we know about its location .  Please explain like I'm five.
Answers.llama2: In layman's terms, the Heisenberg Uncertainty Principle states that there is a fundamental limit to how precisely we can know certain things about the world at the same time.For example, imagine you are trying to measure the speed of a car. If you use a speedometer, you can measure the car's speed very precisely, but then you can't know exactly where the car is located. This is because the speedometer only tells you how fast the car is moving, not where it is.On the other hand, if you use a GPS device to track the car's location, you can know exactly where the car is, but you can't measure its speed very precisely. This is because the GPS device only tells you where the car is, not how fast it is moving.In this way, the Heisenberg Uncertainty Principle says that there is a fundamental trade-off between how precisely we can know two things about the world at the same time. In other words, if we want to know one thing very precisely, we can't know another thing as precisely.So, in simple terms, the Heisenberg Uncertainty Principle is like a game of Simon Says where you can only focus on one thing at a time. If you try to focus on two things at once, you can't know them both very precisely.
Answers.llama3: So, you know how sometimes you try to catch a butterfly or a ball, and it's hard to do because it's moving around and you can't quite get a good look at it?Heisenberg's uncertainty principle is kind of like that. It's a rule in science that says that when we try to measure some things, like how fast something is moving or where it is, we can't do it perfectly at the same time.Think of it like trying to take a picture of a fast-moving car. If you try to focus on the car's speed, you might not be able to see exactly where it is on the road. And if you try to focus on exactly where the car is on the road, you might not be able to see how fast it's going. You can't do both at the same time!This is because, at a really tiny scale, like with atoms and particles, things are moving around really fast and they're hard to pin down exactly. So, when we try to measure them, we have to make some choices about what we want to know more about - whether it's their speed or their location - and we can't know everything at the same time.For example, imagine you're trying to measure the speed of a tiny particle, like an electron. If you want to know exactly how fast it's going, you need to shine a light on it, which means you're going to disturb its path a little bit. So, you can't know exactly where it is at that moment. And if you want to know exactly where it is, you need to look really closely, but that means you can't know exactly how fast it's going.It's kind of like trying to play a game of hide-and-seek with a friend - if you want to find out where they are, you need to listen really carefully, but if you do that, you won't know how fast they're moving around!So, that's Heisenberg's uncertainty principle in a nutshell!
Answers.chatGpt3: Heisenberg's uncertainty principle is a fundamental idea in quantum mechanics, which is a theory that describes how very small things (like atoms and subatomic particles) behave. According to the uncertainty principle, it is impossible to know both the exact position and the exact momentum (speed and direction) of a particle at the same time. This might seem strange, but imagine trying to measure the position of a small insect flying around a room. If you want to know exactly where the insect is, you might try to shine a flashlight on it. But as soon as you shine the light on the insect, you change its momentum (because the light has energy, and when it hits the insect it gives some of that energy to the insect). So now you know where the insect is, but you don't know its momentum as well as you did before. On the other hand, if you don't shine any light on the insect, you might be able to figure out its momentum (for example, by clapping your hands and trying to chase it), but now you don't know its position as well as you did before. The uncertainty principle tells us that there is always a trade-off between knowing the position and knowing the momentum of a particle. The more precisely we know one of these things, the less precisely we can know the other. This is a fundamental aspect of the nature of the universe at very small scales, and it has important implications for how we understand the world around us.
